conversation.message:
Hi Parent_B—happy to share more detail.

1) Daily schedule & hours
- Core day runs roughly 8:30–15:30, with arrival typically in the 8:30–9:15 window and pick-up 15:00–15:30.
- If you need earlier drop-off or later pick-up, tell me your ideal windows—we can confirm what’s available and whether an extended-day arrangement is possible.

2) Teacher-to-child ratio & staff continuity
- We staff to a small-group model with consistent key-person coverage (a primary educator who anchors communication and settling-in).
- We prioritize continuity: stable room teams, limited rotations, and planned handoffs when staffing changes are unavoidable.
- If you share your child’s age, I can give the specific ratio for that classroom band.

3) Supporting transitions (phased entry & communication)
- Phased entry is our default: short initial stays, then gradually extending time over 1–2 weeks depending on how your child settles.
- Daily parent communication during the first weeks (quick written updates + brief handover at drop-off/pick-up), and we set check-in points to adjust the plan.
- We coordinate routines (sleep/comfort items, separation strategies, preferred soothing approaches) so home and school are aligned.

Deadlines / holding a place
- We don’t require you to commit today just for asking questions, but once a family applies and we’re ready to offer a place, we typically ask for a decision within a short window so we can plan staffing and transitions.

To advise you accurately: what age is your child, what schedule (earliest drop-off / latest pick-up) do you need, and when would you realistically be ready to apply if Nursery_D becomes your preferred option?

conversation.message:
Absolutely—happy to share more detail.

1) Daily schedule + balance (free play vs. structured)
A typical day is built around predictable anchors (arrival/circle/meals/rest) with lots of choice-based play in between.
- Arrival (free play + settling-in routines)
- Morning circle (10–15 min): songs, story, calendar/weather, sharing
- Learning-through-play centers (45–60 min): open-choice stations set up by teachers (sensory, blocks, art, early literacy/numeracy games, fine-motor). Teachers rotate to scaffold skills in small moments.
- Outdoor time (30–60 min, daily weather-permitting)
- Lunch
- Rest/quiet time (typically 60–90 min; non-sleepers have quiet activities)
- Afternoon small group (15–25 min): art, music/movement, practical life, or a project tied to children’s interests
- Snack + outdoor/free play
- Pick-up with handover
Overall, it’s mostly play-based with gentle structure: roughly ~65–75% child-led/free play and ~25–35% teacher-guided moments (circle + small groups + embedded instruction during centers).

2) Hours/closures + flexibility
- We operate on core hours with options for early drop-off and late pick-up depending on availability and your needs.
- We follow a published annual calendar with standard public-holiday closures and a small number of staff training days; we share the full closure list in advance so families can plan.
If you tell me your ideal drop-off/pick-up window (and whether you need early/late coverage regularly or only occasionally), I can confirm what we can accommodate.

3) Social-emotional support (transitions, conflict resolution)
- Transitions: we use consistent routines, visual cues, and “first/then” language; we give countdown warnings and offer small jobs (line leader, helper) to make transitions smoother.
- Co-regulation: teachers model calm breathing/label emotions (“I see you’re frustrated”) and offer choices (“You can try again, ask for help, or take a break”).
- Conflict resolution: we coach children to (a) name the problem, (b) listen/reflect, (c) propose solutions (take turns, trade, play together, choose another material), and (d) follow through with support. We stay close, especially for younger children, and gradually fade support as skills grow.
- Communication: we share patterns we notice (e.g., separation anxiety, biting/hitting phases) and align on consistent strategies with families.

If you’re open to it, I’d love to learn a bit about your child (age/temperament) and what matters most to your family (e.g., outdoor time, nap needs, separation support, allergies, language exposure). That will help me be specific about how we’d support them here—and we can also arrange a short visit/tour if you’d like.

- Naps/rest: We keep a predictable rest window after lunch. Children who sleep do so on their own mat/bed space; non-sleepers have quiet activities (books, puzzles) with close supervision so everyone can rest.
- Toileting: We support both toilet-trained children and those still learning. We use routine bathroom visits, gentle reminders, and consistent language, and we coordinate closely with families on cues/schedules. Accidents are handled calmly and discreetly.
- New-starter transitions: We use a phased settling-in plan (short initial days if helpful), a consistent key adult, and familiar routines. We also use visual cues and “first/then” language, plus quick, confident handovers at drop-off to reduce separation stress. We’ll align with you on comfort items, drop-off scripts, and any known triggers.

3) Visits / open house / virtual tour
- Yes—both in-person visits and a short virtual tour are available.
- I can offer a brief 15–20 minute virtual walkthrough, or a 30–45 minute on-site visit (ideally during a calm activity block so you can see the room in action).

If you tell me (a) your preferred days/times this week or next and (b) your child’s age + nap/toileting status, I’ll propose 2–3 specific slots and tailor the details to the exact room they’d join. If Nursery_E is on your shortlist, we’d love to host you soon.

Of course—happy to share the practical details.

1) Tuition/fee structure (registration/materials, payment schedule, discounts)
- Registration/enrollment: one-time registration fee to hold a place once you decide to enroll.
- Materials: a modest annual materials fee to cover classroom supplies (art/sensory, etc.).
- Tuition payments: typically billed monthly in advance (with an option for term/annual payment depending on family preference).
- Discounts: sibling discount is available when siblings are enrolled concurrently; we can also discuss an early-pay option if you prefer term/annual payment.
If you tell me your child’s age group and whether you’re considering full-time or part-time, I can quote the exact monthly figure and the current registration/materials amounts.

2) Part-time vs full-time + changing schedules mid-year
- We offer both full-time and part-time schedules (availability can vary by room/age group).
- Schedule changes mid-year are possible when capacity allows; we try to accommodate increases in days first (e.g., moving from 3 days to 5). Reducing days can be trickier because it impacts staffing, but we’ll always talk through options.
- If you anticipate a change (new job hours, new sibling, etc.), it helps to flag it early so we can plan.

3) Day-to-day communication (app, photos/updates, check-ins)
- Daily: quick handover at drop-off/pick-up plus a short daily note (highlights like meals/rest/mood and any key moments).
- Updates/photos: we share periodic photo updates and classroom highlights (with family permissions) so you can see what your child is engaging in.
- Deeper check-ins: scheduled parent-teacher check-ins during the year, and you can request an additional meeting anytime if something comes up (sleep/toileting transitions, separation anxiety, peer conflicts, etc.).

If you’re comfortable sharing: (a) the schedule you’re considering (days + drop-off/pick-up window), and (b) your child’s age, I’ll respond with the exact fee quote and the most realistic schedule options. Hi Parent_B—thanks for reaching out. I’m glad Nursery_E is on your serious shortlist, and I’m happy to answer each point clearly.

1) Daily routine + learning/play approach
Our day is built around predictable anchors (arrival, circle, meals, rest) with lots of child-led learning-through-play in between.
- Arrival + settling/free play
- Morning circle (songs/story/sharing; ~10–15 min)
- Learning-through-play centers (sensory, blocks, art, early literacy/numeracy games; teachers scaffold in small groups and 1:1 moments)
- Outdoor time (daily, weather permitting)
- Lunch
- Rest/quiet time (non-sleepers have calm activities)
- Afternoon small-group activity (art/music/movement/practical life/project work)
- Snack + outdoor/free play
Overall it’s play-based with gentle structure: lots of choice and exploration, with intentional teacher-guided moments woven in.

2) Hours + flexibility for working parents
We have core hours and, depending on availability, options for early drop-off and late pick-up. We try to be practical for working families while keeping routines predictable for children.
If you tell me your ideal drop-off/pick-up window (and whether you need early/late coverage regularly or occasionally), I’ll confirm what we can accommodate right now.

3) Transitions for new children + communication with families
Transitions/settling-in:
- A phased start can be used (shorter initial days if helpful)
- A consistent “key adult” to build security
- Clear routines, visual cues, and “first/then” language
- Support for separation at drop-off with a consistent handover plan agreed with you
Communication:
- Daily handover at drop-off/pick-up plus a brief daily note (meals/rest/mood/highlights)
- Periodic photos/class updates (with permissions)
- Scheduled check-ins during the year, and additional meetings anytime something needs attention (sleep/toileting/separation/peer conflicts)

4) Timeline after an application is submitted
Typically:
- Application received → we confirm receipt quickly
- If a place is available/appropriate for the age group, we’ll schedule a short visit (or virtual tour) if you haven’t already
- Offer/confirmation: once we’re aligned on start date and schedule, we can usually confirm the place promptly; the place is then held once enrollment paperwork and the registration/holding fee are completed by the stated deadline.

To make this concrete and fast for you: what’s your child’s age and the schedule you’re aiming for (days per week + target drop-off/pick-up)? If you’d like, I can also propose 2–3 tour/virtual slots so you can decide quickly.
